And massive harvester at the entrance, loaded with sugarcane, was more than a display - it’s a symbol of the industry that helped shape "The Sweetest Town in America." As Fox 4’s Hendry County Community Correspondent, Austin Schargorodski works in the area every day, so he met with U.S. Sugar to explore how Clewiston’s sugar industry built the town - and how the festival honors that legacy. Banners were up, antique tractors on display, and the stage was set to celebrate Clewiston’s roots. At the center of it - U.S. Sugar, the company that’s been harvesting there for nearly a century. Austin Schargorodski Line of antique tractors on display at the Clewiston Sugar Festival “We’re in the middle of our 94th harvest,” said Ryan Duffy, U.S. Sugar’s Director of Corporate Communications. “And it’s the center of this community - farming - and sugarcane farming in particular.” Duffy tells me the Florida sugar industry supplies 23% of the country’s sugar! And U.S Sugar's all starts right here, in Clewiston’s rich, muck soil. Inside their tent, an exhibit shows why this land is ideal for growing sugarcane. Austin Schargorodski Handful of Clewiston's muck soil “The hundreds and thousands of years of decomposition to the soil from the water in Lake Okeechobee has given us the nutrient-rich and natural muck soils that we have,” Duffy explained. “It’s highly organic, and that’s what the sugarcane and other crops are grown in.” As the sugar industry grew, so did Clewiston. Duffy says the Sugar Festival started as a celebration of the harvest’s end - but Clewiston Commissioner Hillary Hyslope says it’s also about honoring the people behind it. Austin Schargorodski Hillary Hyslope, Clewiston Commissioner “We enjoy very much coming out to celebrate the industry and all of its people too,” Hislope said. “The people who farm, the people who work day in and day out to keep all of this going.” Tim Burke tells me he spent 31 years as a mechanic for U.S. Sugar. He says this festival brings the community together - just like the industry has for decades. Austin Schargorodski Tim Burke, Clewiston resident “This community sticks together when it’s rough times,” Burke said. “And now they can enjoy themselves with everyone coming to this Sugar Fest.” Saturday’s sweet celebration brings Clewiston together with historical exhibits, live music, food vendors, and a kid's carnival. Over the years our festival has grown into a multi-day event, beginning with sports tournaments and a Miss Sugar Pageant leading up to the main festival day, followed by a Friday Night Kickoff concert with food trucks on festival weekend. On Saturday, the main festival day, attendees can enjoy free live music concerts, an antique tractor display, a car show, a free kids play park, visit a local baking contest and a professional baking display, plus enjoy the offerings of various food and crafts vendors present. Here’s what you can expect at this year’s festival: Start the day off with our 5K & 10K Country Music Run with a lot of hype, great music, and plenty of friends and family on Saturday, March 15, 2025. The race starts promptly at 8:00 am, with “day of” registration and early registration check-in starting at 7:00 am. Visit Clewiston Sugar Fest clewistonsugarfestival.com to sign ups! Cornhole Tournament kicking off on Saturday, March 15, 2025 at 9:00am Tournament will start at 10:00am. $50 per team / $25 Per Person. Horseshoe Tournament will take place on Saturday, March 15, 2025 during the Sugar Festival event. This is an open doubles tournament. All ages welcome. Team Check-In 9:00 a.m. – 10:00 a.m. Start of Tournament 10:00 a.m. $20 per team. The SWEET TASTE Competition will be held at the 38th Annual Clewiston Sugar Festival. Saturday, March 15, 2025; St. Margarets Catholic Church Parish Hall ; Contestants may be amateurs. Professional chefs, cooks or businesses may NOT enter the contest. Contestants may have more than one entry for judging. Submissions must be home cooked. Drop Off: 7:30 AM – 9:00 AM | Judging: 9:00 AM – 11:00 AM | Public Viewing: 11AM – 1:00PM THERE’S MORE?! Of course! When you join us for the Sugar festival in Clewiston you can also expect am Antique Tractor Display, Kids Park, Gator & Wildlife Shows, Line Dancing Lessons, Car Show, and of course Sugar Express -LOCAL RIDE Operating March 15, 2025 | Departure times: 12:00, 2:30 PM and 4:30 PM Departing from 900 WC Owen Avenue One one-hour trips aboard steam-powered train Sugar Express No. 148 Tickets are $30.00 + tax per person | Children 3 and under and not occupying a seat ride free. So, mark your calendars, dust off your cowboy boots, and get ready for a sugar-infused weekend at the Clewiston Sugar Festival! Snively, Vice President, Citrus Groves Elaine Wood, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer Ryan Duffy Senior Director of Corporate Communications Ryan Duffy Director of Corporate Communications Ryan is the Director of Corporate Communications for U.S. Sugar, a position he has held since 2017. In this role, Duffy handles corporate media relations and public engagement at the state and local levels. Additionally, Duffy is responsible for managing U.S. Sugar’s social and digital media initiatives. Previously, he served as a Vice President at Hill+Knowlton Strategies in Tallahassee and worked closely with U.S. Sugar’s communications and public affairs teams for several years. Duffy previously served as communications director to former House Speaker Will Weatherford and as a speechwriter to former U.S. Senators George LeMieux, Mel Martinez, and former Florida Governor Jeb Bush. Duffy holds a master’s in Political Management from George Washington University and a bachelor’s from Florida State University. He is a member of the Florida Chamber Foundation Board of Directors, Florida’s Take Stock in Children Board of Directors, the Florida Gulf Coast University School of Agribusiness Advisory Council, his local Rotary chapter, and a member of his local parish council. In his free time, he coaches youth baseball and soccer. He and his wife Danielle reside in Clewiston with their two children. Brannan Thomas Director of Community Relations Brannan Thomas Director of Community Relations Brannan is the Director of Community Relations for U.S. Sugar. In this role, Thomas manages the company’s community support and engagement initiatives, serving the Glades and coastal communities where the people of U.S. Sugar live and work. Thomas is responsible for overseeing U.S. Sugar’s generous community outreach efforts in the towns, groups, and organizations the company supports. Previously, Thomas served as Director of Business Development for Transworld M & A , a corporate sales and advisory firm based in Fort Lauderdale. He spent nearly 5 years working in the franchise and business sales industry and served as the Southeastern Vice President for United Franchise Group in West Palm Beach.  Part of Brannan’s Community Relations outreach involves sitting on a number of boards. The impressive list includes the Glades Area Boys & Girls Club, Clewiston Chamber of Commerce, Hendry County Economic Development Council, Clewiston Sugar Festival. He is also a trustee with the Central Palm Beach County Chamber Board, and the Sugar Industry Labor Management Committee. Brannan is a native of the Glades region - born in Pahokee and raised in Belle Glade. He is a proud product of the local school systems where he attended Rosenwald Elementary, Lakeshore Middle, Glades Central and graduated from Glades Day School. Thomas excelled in football, basketball, and baseball. He played football at Lehigh University and graduated with a degree in environmental science. Thomas’ community involvement also includes extensive coaching experience working with athletes in Palm Beach County. For three years, Thomas coached varsity football and middle school baseball at the King’s Academy in Royal Palm Beach. He also coached defensive backs at Cheyney University , the nation’s first historically black college and university (HBCU) located in Pennsylvania. Thomas resides in Clewiston with his wife and two children.
